dialogues.speaker: JACK SCANS THE AREA 37
dialogues.text: looking to make sure there's nothing that needs an urgent response. He finds one MAN, 45 in a suit, who lies on the ground, unconscious. BLEEDING BADLY from the head. Jack pulls open the Man's jacket -- TO REVEAL A PIECE OF METAL SHRAPNEL STUCK INTO HIS STOMACH. Seeing this, Jack's eyes go flush with concern. He checks SHRAPNEL MAN's pulse -- pulls open his eyelids. Jack delicately removes the man's jacket, drapes it over him, forming a makeshift BLANKET. Jack turns to the ripped-ope end of the fuselage -- where first class and the cockpit would normally be --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSIDE the fuselage, looking out, the tumultuous OCEAN fr by this giant shattered aluminum tube. It's a disorientin shot, since the plane is BANKED ON ITS SIDE. At this angl SEATS are on a SIDE WALL, the wreckage-strewn floor actua a long row of windows. And Jack appears, looking into the fuselage -- and we PUS ON HIM. What Jack sees -- despite his ER training -- sick him. Then Boone arrives, urgent, holding a HANDFUL OF PEN

dialogues.speaker: BOONE
dialogues.text: -- I didn't know which one would work best. For a long beat, Jack's eyes don't leave the fuselage. Finally he looks at Boone. And the pens. And tears well i Jack's eyes -- the whole experience finally catching up t him. Jack takes all of the pens, saying, softly, emotionally, kindly:

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: ...They're all good. Thanks... And Jack walks off, past Boone, who turns, watching Jack

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fifty-yard distance from the wreckage, a fellow survivo stands here, staring almost angrily at the wrecked plane. He's 35, handsome, with a cocky, self-centered vibe. And he's smoking. Meet SAWYER. A few others recover about here -- including another Man, approaches. 25. English rocker. Self-deprecating -- somewhere between an adult and a child. This is CHARLIE. These two have never spoken. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  11.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE SAWYER
dialogues.text: -- You, uh... s'cuse me, ya sure you should be smoking--? -- You sure you want me to shove my foot up your ass? A beat.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Okay. Excellent, just... thought I'd raise it. Charlie walks off. A beat later, he returns --

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -- Mind if I... bum one then? Thanks... Charlie takes a cig from tough Sawyer, then walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC: Synthesizer DRONE. A surreal post-disaster moment. LONG LENS SHOT as Jack, for the first time appearing vulnerable -- perhaps even weak -- near the jet's open CA DOOR. He rummages through a stranger's SUITCASE... other bags he's already searched beside it. As he ZIPS open someone's TOILETRY BAG --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cluster of trees off the beach. The SHATTERED JET barel visible in the distance. Jack walks in here, getting away from the others. TIGHT SHOTS as he sets down, on a large rock, a TRAVEL SE KIT. A LIGHTER. A T-shirt. And in some pain, Jack pulls off his jacket -- revealing enormous BLOOD STAIN and RIP on the side of his shirt. He carefully removes his shirt. Looks down at the LARGE SLAS

dialogues.speaker: HIS BACK.
dialogues.text: Christ, he did all that with this crash wound. He twists, trying to figure out how best to sew himself u He angles around -- can't find a good way to approach thi And we watch him for a long beat, feeling for Jack as he tries to solve this painful puzzle. Frustrated but needin help, Jack looks around -- we pop to a TIGHT SHOT as he s something off-camera. Something that makes him stop... +. and we see his point of view: walking, slowly, seeming aimless through the brush, is a WOMAN. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  41 12. CONTINUED: 4l She's thirty feet away, her back to us. Jack watches her a moment. Then he calls out:

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Excuse me! And this woman turns. Her face pale, ghostly. Wracked in stress. Eyes wet. This is KATE. Pretty, 26 years-old. Smart. Trustworthy. And, in all the important ways, entirely untested.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: D'y'ever use a needle? And Kate just stares at him for a moment, disoriented.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: ...d-- what?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Have you ever patched up a pair of jeans?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (beat, about to cry) I... I made the drapes in my apartment

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: That's fantastic -- d'you have a second? I need a little help. Kate takes a post-traumatic-stress-disorder beat, then mo forward, through the trees. She arrives at Jack.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: ..-Help with what? And Jack turns, SHOWING HER THE WOUND.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: This. And her eyes just close.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'd do it myself -- I'ma doctor -- but I just can't reach it.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (eyes closed) You want me to sew that up. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  13.

dialogues.speaker: JACK KATE
dialogues.text: It's just like drapes, same -- No, I used a sewing thing-- machine on the drapes --

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You can do this, I'm telling you. If you wouldn't mind. A beat. Finally Kate snaps into agreement: she'll do it.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -- Thank you -- And Jack pulls from his pocket the mini bottle of VODKA. Holds it out to her, as if offering a drink. Odd. Then:

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's for your hands. Understanding now, she takes the vodka, cleans her hands it.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Save some for me. (off her look; smiles) The wound. She nods, gives back the half empty bottle as he gives he the needle and thread:

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're gonna have to sterilize the needle. She takes the stuff, using the lighter to heat the needle Jack sits on the rock, sucks in a sharp intake of breath he pours the remaining vodka over his wound -- it fucking

dialogues.speaker: STINGS --
dialogues.text: Kate's finished with the needle -- considers the SIX COLO OF THREAD in the travel sewing kit.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Any, uh... color preference? Jack looks at her -- there it was, the first flash of her personality.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Standard black. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  41

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Kate nods, trying to stay cool, pulling out a length of b thread and threads the needle. Kate then kneels beside hi and after a beat she starts to sew his skin. Then:

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: So I might throw up on you.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (it hurts, but:) You're doing fine. He watches her, this pretty young woman he doesn't know, stitching him back together again, trying to keep her composure. CLOSE ON her hands. No jewelry, no watch.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You live in New York? God, she just wants to lose it. But she doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: ++. I used to. I've been in New Zealand. About a year.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: ...How come?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Oh, I just... had to get away -- -- And suddenly Kate is crying. It just caught up to her, that's all. And she weeps, resting her head on the back o her hand. Jack suddenly feels guilty, watching this kind stranger weep. So he speaks, quietly, sweetly:

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: ..-Hey... hey, listen, I can get someone else to do this--

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: -- No. No, I'm okay. And Kate gathers her strength -- shows a small sign that she's not someone to give up. She SNIFFLES, gathers herse Knows she must. She continues sewing.

dialogues.speaker: KATE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You don't seem afraid at all. I don't understand that.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Fear's sort of an odd thing. It's like an in-law who just drops in. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  41

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You don't like it, but you can't just get rid of it. It's a struggle. But you have to learn to deal with it or it'll make you insane.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I haven't had much success with fear. Sensing she needs some help as she works on him, Jack off

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: When I was in residency, my first solo procedure was a spinal surgery on a sixteen year-old kid. Girl. (beat) At the end of it -- thirteen hours later -- I was closing her up... and I... I accidentally ripped her dural sack -- you know what that is? Kate has stopped sewing, now staring at him.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's at the base of the spine, where all the nerves come together. Membrane as thin as tissue. So it ripped open -- the nerves just spilled out like angel hair pasta-- her spinal fluid flowing out and I just... froze. 'Cause I knew. If I didn't get those nerves back in that sack and sew it up... those thirteen hours were for nothing, that girl would be paralyzed. I had about a minute. (beat) And all the assistants were just watching me, I could feel their eyes. And the terror was so... crazy, so real... and I knew I had to deal with it. So I just made a choice. I'd let the fear in. Let it take over. Let it do its thing. (looks at Kate) But only for five seconds. That's all I was gonna give it. So I started to count to five. I could feel it inside -- like when you drink a milkshake on a hot day. (beat) One, two, three, four, five. (beat) And it was gone. I got back to work. Sewed her up. She was fine. Kate breathes again, returns to stitching him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  41 42 43 16.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think everyone has something like that. A moment where you establish your relationship with fear. And either you learn to deal with it... or you don't. From Kate, a little, sad laugh:

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: If that had been me... I think I would've run for the closest door.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: No, I don't think that's true. (then) You're not running now. And Kate stops -- looks up at him. Her eyes clearly sayin "Oh yes I am."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun drops below the horizon. The sky turning a miraculous purple-red. Claire watches the sunset. At another part of the beach, Locke watches the sunset.

dialogues.speaker: THE LARGE BONFIRE
dialogues.text: A MAN WANDERS into frame. Stops. Checks his CELL PHONE. Holds it in the air. Takes another few steps. Checks it again. This ritual has been going on for awhile. CAMERA PULLS BACK past a 40 year-old Middle Eastern man, SAYID, along with Boone (the former lifeguard) and a few others, throw PALM FRONDS to make it even bigger. Sayid turns -- sees Charlie (our English rocker), sitting alone clutching his legs, looking like he's got the chills.

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: You! What's your name? Charlie's head snaps to Sayid:

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: -- What -- sorry -- Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: Charlie, we need some help with the fire! No one will see it if it isn't big! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  43 44 45 46 17.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (getting up, helping) -- Right! I'm on it! What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: Sayid.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: -- Sayid! I am oniit, Sayid! TRACK CHARLIE as he goes for more fronds -- CAMERA STOPPI ON ROSE, the woman Jack resuscitated, who sits on the san near the fire, a blanket wrapped around her. Lit by the fire, she's taking a man's WEDDING BAND and stringing it her necklace, turning the ring into a pendant.

dialogues.speaker: FIVE BONFIRES
dialogues.text: Spread out across the beach, groups of EIGHT to TWELVE SURVIVORS huddle around them. And we get a sense now of h many have survived: forty-seven people. One of the fires particularly big --

dialogues.speaker: A KOREAN COUPLE 45
dialogues.text: 30's. Her name is SUN, his is JIN. Both scratched up, neither seriously wounded. She sits, he kneels before her holding her face in his hands. Talks to her IN KOREAN, deeply caring. She's just nodding, agreeing with whatever is he asks. Those who speak Korean understand:

dialogues.speaker: JIN
dialogues.text: (in KOREAN) I want you to stay in my sight at all times. If I walk away, you follow. We need to stay together, do you understand me? We cannot be apart. -- And as he continues, Hurley CROSSES FRAME -- we FOLLOW NOW. He carries two dozen THAWED-OUT AIRPLANE MEALS. He arrives at:

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE 46
dialogues.text: The pregnant woman, who sits in a disembodied Business Cl chair on the beach. She rests comfortably. Relatively speaking, she's doing fine. Hurley offers her a meal:

dialogues.speaker: HURLEY
dialogues.text: Hungry? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  18.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: (sweetly, taking it) -- Yeah. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: HURLEY
dialogues.text: (re: contractions) Any more, uh... you know, baby stuff?

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: No. No... I'm all right. Hurley's glad. Hands her some plastic silverware:

dialogues.speaker: HURLEY
dialogues.text: Hang in there.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Yeah. You too. Hurley nods confidently and walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHANNON (the 20 year-old girl who was just screaming her off before) sits on the beach beside a small FIRE, painti her toenails, of all things. She's composed now, but stil coming down from the experience. After a beat, Boone sits closely beside her on the sand, facing her. Watches her paint her toenails. There's something clear here: there's enormous animosity between them. Regardless, he offers her a chocolate bar.

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON
dialogues.text: As if I'm gonna start eating chocolate. He wants to kill her.

dialogues.speaker: BOONE
dialogues.text: How are your toenails coming.

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON
dialogues.text: They're fine, thanks. A beat. Boone stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: BOONE
dialogues.text: Shannon, we might be here a while (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  19.

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON BOONE
dialogues.text: I can go a day without eating if I have to. We might be here longer than a day.

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON
dialogues.text: The plane had a black box, idiot. They know exactly where we are, they're coming. (beat, then: ) Lemme guess. You don't think they are.

dialogues.speaker: BOONE
dialogues.text: No, I'm pretty sure they're not.

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON
dialogues.text: Why.

dialogues.speaker: BOONE
dialogues.text: Because you're so sure they are.

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON
dialogues.text: You're such an ass.

dialogues.speaker: BOONE
dialogues.text: While that may be true, I am still -- I swear to God for reasons I will never understand -- concerned about your survival. And he offers the candy bar again. Shannon just looks at him. All resentment. And while she's hungry, she says:

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON
dialogues.text: I'll eat on the rescue boat. She goes back to her nails. Boone knows that's a pipe dre Resenting her in equal measure, he rips open the bar and starts eating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Locke, the man Jack recruited to help save Shrapnel Man, on a piece of curved jet wreckage, which almost looks lik modernist sculpture. Locke just stares out at the crashin water. Eyes fixed on the nothingness out there. Hurley approaches.

dialogues.speaker: HURLEY
dialogues.text: We got chicken or lasagna. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  20.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A long beat. Locke doesn't move. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: HURLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They're not cooked, but they can't be worse cold than they were heated. Locke doesn't look away from the night sea. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: HURLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello? But Locke still doesn't respond.

dialogues.speaker: HURLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay, you too. And Hurley just walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RIIIIIP: Jack rips open Shrapnel Man's shirt. The metal piece still embedded in this breathing-but-unconscious ma belly. It's a dirty, bloody mess. Jack kneels over him, checking the wound. Kate sits close, watching intently. BONFIRES in the background.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: -- Why aren't you removing that?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Because it could be holding his stomach together. Pulling this out could cause more damage than leaving it until help comes. (then) His head wound's bad too.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: .-.-Is he gonna live?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I could tell you a lot more if there was a CAT scan around. Kate can't take her eyes off the Man. Jack turns to her a sees this. Realizes there's a connection between them:

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ++-Do you know him?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (beat, staring) ...-He was sitting next to me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  21.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: And Jack feels for her. Wishes he could fix all of this. But he can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we FAVOR a nine year-old boy -- WALT -- who lies here his side, covered in layers of clothing to keep him warm. His eyes are open, staring off. His father, MICHAEL, 32, lies beside him.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Hey. Walt. Sure you're warm enough?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: (a whisper) ...Yeah. Michael wants to make it better for his son -- somehow -- he can't think of one thing to do or say. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Love you. And we just hold. Walt not saying a thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Imagine the most spectacular view of the stars visible fr Earth.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We must've been close to 40,000 feet when it happened. Then a crude MODEL OF A PLANE appears -- maybe eight inch long, CUT out of that BANANA LEAF, and held by Jack's HAN

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: When we hit a pocket of dead air. Now we see that we are:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bonfires and other survivors in the distance. Jack and Ka are together here, using a piece of wreckage as a table. Jack holds the model plane, re-enacting the pre-crash moments, trying to make sense of it all. Kate's hands are clasped at her mouth as she watches, closely, intensely. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  52

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: We dropped. Must've been two-hundred feet. The turbulence that followed... by far the worst I've ever been through... but turbulence doesn't bring down planes. (beat) Electrical power came in and out. Sounded like the hydraulics went out. It was pretty clear what was happening. (beat) How long would you say that lasted?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: ...Five minutes?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's what I was thinking... (beat) There was too much stress on the structure of the plane. (beat) That's when the tail broke away. And Jack snaps off the tail -- he now, slowly, turns the fuselage, rolling it -- and you can imagine how terrifyin this actually was -- as he does this, Kate watches the mo tears in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -- We were out of control. We actually went up for a while. Then dropping... flipping... (then, it occurs to him) What row where you in?
(then) ...I blacked out. And God, this is the worst memory of all time. Still, Kat fights for her composure as she says:

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (unfortunately) I didn't. (beat, with dread) I saw the whole thing. We were falling... I knew the tail was gone. I couldn't make myself look back. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  23.

dialogues.speaker: KATE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (then) Then the... the front section came apart. Jack rips off the nose section -- slowly cartwheeling the leaf model...

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: -- Did it hit something?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: It might have. (beat, wipes away a tear) We crashed maybe five seconds later. And Jack lets the model come down -- in a position resemb what we saw at the opening. The ANGLE IS LOW NOW -- MACRO it looks like the opening in model form. Jack considers this. Sort of studies the image, trying to figure it out.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: The front end of the fuselage isn't on the beach. Neither's the tail. I woke up about five hundred yards away from the beach... must've fallen out while the fuselage was cartwheeling... (realizes his own amazing luck; then) We need to figure out which way we came in.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Why.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Because there's a chance we could find the cockpit. If it's still intact, there could be a transceiver. That would let us send a signal, help a rescue party find us.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (a little bit of awe) How do you know all that?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I took a couple of flying lessons. (forces a smile) Wasn't for me.

dialogues.speaker: KATE JACK
dialogues.text: I saw some smoke. From the beach -- about a mile inland. -- Where? (pointing) -- through the valley. From the jungle, there. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  52 53

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: His eyes on the blackness of the night. As he stares, in gut knowing it's the cockpit, Kate says:

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: If you're going for the cockpit, I'm going with you. (determined) We'll leave as soon as it's light. Jack can't help but delight in this resolute young woman.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I don't know your name.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I'm Kate.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Jack. (smiles) So what were you doing in New Zealand? Now that the topic of conversation has shifted, Kate stif momentarily. Then --

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Everything. Feels like. (off Jack's curiosity) I was, uh... mixing paint for a while. At a hardware store. I worked for a veterinarian, in Lumsden.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Lumsden.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (enough about me, pal) So what's up with the tattoos, Jack? You one of those really hardcore spinal surgeons or what? Now it's JACK's turn to stiffen. But before he can answer MWOOOOOOQOOQO000ORRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRR! Jack and Kate tur listening to --

dialogues.speaker: BEFORE
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  54 55 56 57 25.

dialogues.speaker: OTHER SURVIVORS 54
dialogues.text: Turn in the distance, looking, scared as Kate enters fram FOREGROUND -- in EXTREME CLOSEUP --

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (at a whisper) ...What was that...? And Jack walks up behind her, looking out -- with no answ

dialogues.speaker: LOCKE 55
dialogues.text: PUSH IN ON HIM as he turns back toward the jungle -- seat as he has been for hours, staring out to sea. Locke doesn seem scared as much as accepting of whatever challenge th is. This guy's somehow accepted his mortality in a way th can only, inevitably, be frightening.

dialogues.speaker: WALT AND MICHAEL 56
dialogues.text: The boy's sitting up -- eagerly reacting to the sound -- somehow HOPEFUL -- Michael seen behind him, concerned -- looking toward the distant jungle --

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: -- I think that's Vincent --

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (beat, afraid) -- That's not Vincent --

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE 57
dialogues.text: Mid-way through her meal, Claire is turned, eyes on the distant jungle valley --

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: -- Did anyone hear that sound -- ? DOLLY to find Hurley, getting to his feet and moving forw

dialogues.speaker: HURLEY
dialogues.text: ...I think, uh... unfortunately all of us did. Suddenly -- THE SOUND AGAIN -- and -- WORSE -- Hurley TUR toward the source of the SOUND -- Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  58 59 60 61 62 63 26.

dialogues.speaker: TREES 58
dialogues.text: Distant 50-foot tall TREES SWAY -- hundreds of yards away PAN to Jack and Kate -- who step forward -- moving closer the scary SOUND --

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON AND BOONE 59
dialogues.text: Sitting, but already alert --

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON
dialogues.text: -- Okay... this isn't funny-- Boone gets up -- moves to get closer to maybe see somethi Shannon is on her feet, pissed --

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -- Boone -- wait -- !

dialogues.speaker: SAYID AND CHARLIE 60
dialogues.text: ~~ And the Others at the bonfire -- start to move toward noise --

dialogues.speaker: THE GROUP 61
dialogues.text: And all of the characters we've met so far gather on the beach -- in a sort of tiered way -- Jack and Kate near th front. There's a long silence, all of them watching... afraid -- then, suddenly, GASPS as all their heads simultaneously TURN to -- ANOTHER PART OF THE JUNGLE --— 62 where a SERIES OF DISTANT TREES SWAY as if something SCAR BIG is moving -- A FEW ACRES IN SECONDS -- this huge THIN whatever the hell it is -- seems to be disappearing into jungle --

dialogues.speaker: -- AN WE HOLD ON OUR TERRIFIED MAIN CHARACTERS 63
dialogues.text: for a long beat... until finally...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Terrific. CUT TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: END ACT ONE
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  64 65 27.

dialogues.speaker: OF BLUE.
dialogues.text: And we begin to PULL BACK TO REVEAL:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was Jack's POV -- as he still stares out the window, contemplating something pretty heavy. Then:

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: ...-How's the drink? Jack turns -- looking up at the pretty, Australian FLIGHT ATTENDANT.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (bad) It's good.

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: That wasn't a very strong reaction.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: It's not a very strong drink. So she slips a couple MINI-BOTTLES of VODKA from her cart Jack.

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: (quiet, playful) Shh.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (leans in, sotto, conspiratorial) This of course breaks some critical FAA regulations --

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: I saw you when you got on. Giving your first class ticket to that older lady.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Oh, I wasn't being sweet. She guilted me into it. She's like six-hundred years old and says she's never flown before. (gimme a break) Come on. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  28.

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: You think it's all an act?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I'm pretty sure. Smiling, she walks off, toward the rear of the plane -- w she has words with another Passenger a few rows back. Jac is smiling too, hoping she'll be back again soon. Pleased Jack twists open one of the bottles, empties it into his DRINK. DOWNS the whole thing. He puts the other mini-bottle into his jacket pocket. Unbuckles his seatbelt, gets out of his seat just as CHAR quickly pushes past, heading toward the front of the plan a swift clip -- a man on a mission --

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Sorry...

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Guess he really had to go. Jack smiles at ROSE seated across the row from him. Of course he has no idea that he will, in short order, save woman's life. Suddenly: light TURBULENCE. Just a little. No big deal. DING -- "FASTEN SEATBELTS" LIGHTS UP. Jack becomes visibl tense, does his best not to let it show --

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT ATTENDANT'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentleman, the pilot has turned on the fasten seatbelts sign -- please return to your seats with your seatbelts fastened... Jack glances at Rose, nervously clutching her armrest.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: It's normal.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: (grateful) .»--Oh, I know. (then) I've just never been a good flier. My husband always reminds me that planes want to be in the air.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Well he sounds like a smart man. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  29.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: (smiles) You be sure and tell him that when he gets back from the bathroom. The plane SHAKES again. Jack smiles at Rose... and we alm get the sense it's easier for him to focus on her fear th deal with his own --

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I'll keep you company 'til he does. (clicks seatbelt) Don't worry, it'll be over in a --

dialogues.speaker: OBJECT SLAM TO THE CEILING
dialogues.text: PLANE SHUDDERS VIOLENTLY AND WE SMASH CUT TO -— EXT. BEACH — DAWN 67 CRASHING WAVES and we're TIGHT ON JACK, his eyes focused across the water as the SUN RISES. Remembering the horror the SUN RISES. It's an unadulterated moment of PURE ISLAN BEAUTY -- and Jack, now in a clean white T-shirt, takes i in. We're DOLLYING, Jack in FOREGROUND CLOSEUP, as behind him Survivors are mostly grouped together now -- nobody slept they're all wired, SCARED -- and Walt stands among them, looking up at this strange collection of adults, all talk over each other about that "THING" from the night before

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: It wasn't natural, whatever it was...

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: -- that sound it made -- I keep thinking, there was something familiar about it.

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON
dialogues.text: Really? Where are you from?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: The Bronx.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It could've been something like monkeys.

dialogues.speaker: SAWYER
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm sure it was monkeys. It's Monkey Island. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  67 68 30.

dialogues.speaker: HURLEY
dialogues.text: Technically, you know, we don't even know if we're on an island --

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: (if he knows anything) -- We're on an island. This is all just buzz to Jack -- the same conversation ha been going all night. He's still in his own head space as Kate arrives, close -- almost conspiratorial:

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: You ready? Jack turns to see Kate. She's tired, scared, but determin

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Kate, you showed me where the smoke was. I can get there myself--

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I'm coming with you.

dialogues.speaker: JACK KATE
dialogues.text: I want you to stay here. -- No.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: We don't know what the terrain's gonna be. You're safer if you--

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I can't prove to you that I'm up for it. All I can say is my gym had a rock climbing wall -- and yeah, I realize how pathetic that sounds. (then, firm but simple) I'm going with you. Jack won't argue. Truth is, he wants the company. Then:

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You're gonna need better shoes.

dialogues.speaker: KATE 68
dialogues.text: Near the crash, she's doing the bleak work of pulling boo off a DEAD BODY. She puts them on. They fit. A severe but necessary move. And she looks up -- far across the beach, LOCKE is watching her. A somewhat intense gaze. And Kate thinks for a moment, "Did Locke know the woman whose shoe I'm now wearing?" But in the middle of that question, Loc SMILES -- AND REVEALS AN ORANGE PEEL COVERING HIS TEETH. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  31.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Somehow, this moment just gives Kate the chills. And Lock turns away from her, continuing to PEEL THE ORANGE that h eating.

dialogues.speaker: 15 SURVIVORS 69
dialogues.text: Sitting together. Among them are Boone and Shannon, Sayid Charlie, Michael and Walt.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: -- Anyone have any sunscreen?

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON
dialogues.text: (going for her backpack) Yeah, I do.

dialogues.speaker: HURLEY
dialogues.text: So I was just looking inside the fuselage. It's pretty grim in there. You think we should be doing anything about the, uh... (uncomfortable with Walt) «+. "B-O-D-Y-S"? No one gets his spelling.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: What are you spelling, man, "Bodies"?

dialogues.speaker: WALT SHANNON
dialogues.text: B-O-D-I-E-S. (hands Charlie sunblock) They'11 deal with 'em. When they get here.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (re: sunblock) SPF 2? Do they even make this?

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON
dialogues.text: Fine. She grabs it back as Jack arrives:

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I'm going to look for the cockpit. See if we can find a transceiver to send out a distress signal. Help out the rescue team. (they're surprised, he addresses Boone) You're gonna need to keep an eye on the wounded. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  69

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: And Sawyer 32. 69

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If that guy in the suit wakes up, try to keep him calm -- don't let him remove that piece of shrapnel. You understand?

dialogues.speaker: BOONE
dialogues.text: What about the guy with the leg? Your tourniquet --

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Stopped the bleeding. I took it off last night. He'll be all right.

dialogues.speaker: BOONE
dialogues.text: -- Yeah, okay. Cool -- uh, good job.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (moves to them) -- Hey, I'm coming with -- I wanna help --

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: -- I don't need anymore help --

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: -- No, I wanna go, I'm not too keen on keeping still -- enters the group now:

dialogues.speaker: SAWYER
dialogues.text: Yeah, this is genius. Going into the jungle? After that sound last night? The thing that moved those trees? Yeah, this is a great idea. And Kate arrives --

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (re: sawyer) -- What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: -- Nothing --

dialogues.speaker: SAWYER
dialogues.text: When they show up to rescue us while you're gone? We're not waiting around.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (to Kate) Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: -- Oh, she's coming too? Excellent. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  69 70 33.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: And Charlie actually goes first. Jack and Kate share a lo -- and the two head off after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack cuts a SWATH through the jungle with a large STICK, forging a path of sorts. A man of few words, he's about t yards ahead of -- KATE and CHARLIE. Walking in silence for a beat. Then:

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: You mind if I ask you something?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Me? No, I'd be thrilled -- I've been waiting.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Have we ever met anywhere?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Nah. That would be unlikely.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Hm. They keep walking.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I look familiar though.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You can't quite place it.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: No, I can't.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Yeah, I think I know.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: ...-You do? Then Charlie does something surprising. He starts singing

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: "Till the ennnnnd of time! You know you thought you would be caught -- Till the ennnnd of time...!" (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  70 34.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As he walks, Charlie looks back at her, somehow impressed himself. Kate has no idea what that meant. Jack watches Charlie like he's nuts.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (almost insulted) You still don't get it? You -- Of course I've heard it, I never heard that song? just don't know what the hell that has to --

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -- Well that's why I'm -- that's us! Drive Shaft!

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: -- What?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: God -- have you never heard of bloody Drive Shaft?

dialogues.speaker: KATE CHARLIE
dialogues.text: The band? Yes, the band! -- You were in Drive Shaft? -- Not was, I'm in it! Right now, we're still together, Are you kidding me? I'm the bassist! -- Kidding? No! I'm -- My friend Beth would freak fantastic! With a bass. out, she Gimme Beth's number, I'1l1 loved you -- call her.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (to Jack) You know Drive Shaft? And Jack shakes his head, a grateful "no"...

dialogues.speaker: KATE, (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: -- You don't have to keep using the past tense, you know. We're still together. (as they hike...) In fact, I'm supposed to be in the middle of a comeback. So... And they continue, into the jungle... and now we're on a SHOT of the three of them on their trek -- and we begin t BOOM DOWN and realize... it's actually a POV: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  35.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: (in KOREAN) There's no more room here! Over there! There's room over there! And that Survivor is turned away, running past Michael, w covers his son Walt with a too-large raincoat. Shannon and Boone head toward the wrecked plane -- stoppe Hurley, who yells to them over the NOISE:

So Shannon and Boone head for shelter of some nearby tree And Locke -- odd Locke -- who sits near the shore, eyes closed, head back. Letting the rain fall onto his face. Washing clean all that's come before... And there's Sayid, being smart: he sets up a TARP he's fo in cargo -- using aluminum sticks of wreckage as supports And as soon as it's up, Sawyer enters -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: I need to put up the other side!

dialogues.speaker: SAWYER
dialogues.text: (don't tell me what to do) Yeah, I'm all right in here, Osama. TIGHT on Sayid as he turns to Sawyer. Fury in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: ...What_did you call me?

dialogues.text: -- AND DISTANT TREES SWAY again -- as if the thing is hea into the deep valley -- MOVING -- and we PAN FAST -- we'r UNDER DEBRIS SHELTER -- TIGHT ON CLAIRE'S FACE as she say

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the rain POUNDS, we find Jack, Kate and Charlie, continuing their hike. They finally stop. Their eyes falling upon something -- and we PAN TO SEE IT. It's the COCKPIT. Actually, the entire front SECTION OF T PLANE, smashed badly, UPENDED, resting against a giant tr The characters take it in for a moment. A horrible sight. And as they exchange a look, ready for anything...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOOM DOWN over the massive piece of fuselage as Jack, Kat and Charlie arrive, looking up at the terrifying debris. TRIO moves around the WRECKAGE, twisted metal offering no obvious way in. Kate SPOTS something:

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (shouts over the rain)

dialogues.speaker: OVER_HERE
dialogues.text: Jack and Charlie come to Kate, who indicates a JAGGED OPE AT GROUND LEVEL -- enter-able, but TIGHT. Kate gets on he stomach and CRAWLS into --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kate stands up to find herself -- inside the front sectio the plane. Everything eerily CANTED: all of FIRST CLASS a the FRONT LAVATORIES between her and the COCKPIT. OVERHEA BINS hanging open, the aisles themselves on an ANGLE -- R leaking in -- half a dozen BODIES still in their chairs. Jack emerges from the opening -- Sees Kate is uneasy --

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Let's find your transgizmo and get outta here, yeah? Jack starts to move up the aisle -- fighting GRAVITY -- h to grab onto the SEATS so he doesn't fall... Kate follows him, THE SOUND OF THE RAIN still pounding on shattered hull. Goes without being said -- This is all pretty fucking SCARY. Charlie then crawls through. Stands. Looks up, toward the cockpit. Takes it all in -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  77 78 38.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: God... this is horrible... He starts climbing behind them...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUOUS
dialogues.text: Jack reaches the COCKPIT DOOR. Battered by the crash -- slightly ajar, but still LOCKED. Jack reaches in -- TUGS the door. But it won't open. Jack grabs a CHARRED FIRE EXTINGUISHER...

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (to Kate) -- Get back... And Jack SLAMS the extinguisher down on the DOOR KNOB. Dents, but nothing. SLAMS it down again -- the lock BREAK little -- but it'll take some more SLAMS --

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (HITTING IT with all his MIGHT) Come _on-- come on-- COME ON! BANG! The knob BREAKS off! And Jack drops the extinguishe

dialogues.speaker: -- RIPS OPEN THE DOOR AND THE COPILOT'S BODY FALLS OUT
dialogues.text: Kate SCREAMS -- Jack SHOUTS -- and the body lands RIGHT N

dialogues.speaker: AAAHHH-
dialogues.text: Jack looks to Kate --

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (no) -- Yeah, you?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I'm all right! FYI -- I'm good... And Jack pulls himself up and into: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  39. INT. FRONT SECTION OF THE PLANE - COCKPIT - RAINSTORM — 7

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUOUS
dialogues.text: Rain pours through one of the shattered windows -- though TREE BRANCHES and LEAVES obscures any view. The other windows are intact, but thick with humidity. Branches and leaves also obscure any view to the outside. The instrume panel broken -- some pieces HANGING -- WIRES EXPOSED. And the PILOT's body is here, slumped in his seat. Jack turns back to Kate, who is about to climb up -- but she s the Pilot's body.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (protectively) -- You don't have to come up here--

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: -- No, I'm good. So Jack helps pull up Kate. As he starts searching compartments:

dialogues.speaker: KATE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -- So what does a transceiver look like?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: -- Like a complicated walkie talkie. Kate starts looking for it too. In order to check the Pilot's compartment, she has to pull him back, off the controls. So does, back into his seat and SUDDENLY THE PI JOLTS, AWAKE -- KATE GASPS and Jack, shocked, moves to hi the Pilot COUGHS, disoriented and hurt. Jack unbuckles hi straps -- checks his vitals --

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -- Hey -- can you hear me? (dazed, weak) (to Kate) -- What -- wh -- -- I need the water -- Kate quickly goes through the backpack as Jack undoes the Pilot's tie, loosens his collar -- Kate hands the water t Jack, who gives it to the Pilot -- he drinks a little, co some up. A dried cut on the man's forehead -- his eye closed. Although a pro, the Pilot is on the verge of tear

dialogues.speaker: PILOT
dialogues.text: -- How many -- survived? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  40.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: At least forty-eight. Including you. (Pilot nods, heartsick) -- Anything feel broken? The Pilot slowly, painfully begins to move -- but:

dialogues.speaker: PILOT
dialogues.text: Head hurts -- dizzy...

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Probably a concussion.

dialogues.speaker: PILOT
dialogues.text: -- How long has it been?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Sixteen hours.

dialogues.speaker: PILOT
dialogues.text: -- Sixteen... (then, afraid) -- Has anyone come?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Not yet. Jack and Kate watch as the Pilot closes his eyes, almost pain at the thought. Finally, his voice weak:

dialogues.speaker: PILOT
dialogues.text: Six hours in. Our radio went out. The redundant system... the transponder -- wasn't functioning. No one could see us. (then, with dread) So we turned back. To land in Fiji. (dear God...) When we hit that turbulence... we were over a thousand miles off course -- They'1l be looking in the wrong place. Kate looks to Jack -- this is even worse news than he anticipated.

dialogues.speaker: PILOT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We have a transceiver--

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: -- Good, that's what we were hoping -- And the Pilot tries to stand -- it's hard, he's so bruise (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  79 80 81 41.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You shouldn't try to...

dialogues.speaker: PILOT
dialogues.text: (getting his bearings now) I'm all right. (points to the panel) Transceiver's in there. Kate goes for a compartment -- and pulls out a DAMAGED RA She hands it to the Pilot. He starts to work it -- when J realizes:

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: -- Where's Charlie? Good question. Kate moves back, out of the cockpit. The Pilot keeps trying to radio -- but:

dialogues.speaker: PILOT
dialogues.text: -- It's not working...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kate peeks in -- but Charlie's nowhere to be seen. Played an eerie moment... but then she sees the door to one of t FRONT LAVS is ajar. Hears something INSIDE. Kate climbs back -- peers into the inverted bathroom, whe Charlie's leaning over the toilet bowl --

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: -- Hey, what're you d--? Charlie jumps -- nervous -- turns to her -- we HOLD ON CHARLIE, he doesn't have a fast answer --

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: -- What? Nothing -- But then: MROQOOOWRRRRRRRRROOOOQOQQOOOOOBWWRRRRRRRRRRRRR! shit: the SOUND again. Except this time it's CLOSE --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack turns -- the Pilot freezes --

dialogues.speaker: PILOT JACK
dialogues.text: -- What the hell was that? (whisper yell to the back) Kate! Kate's quickly climbing back in -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  42.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (sotto) -- It's right outside --

dialogues.speaker: PILOT
dialogues.text: -- What's righ -- ?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: -- Shh! -- Whatever it is, it's RIGHT THERE -- stepping now, outs the cockpit -- they're motionless as there's ANOTHER STEP the WIRES in the cockpit SHAKE with the apparent "FOOT" IMPACT -- and a DARK SHAPE CROSSES the window -- Jack SLOWLY climbs up -- on one of the pilot seats -- and uses his hand -- wipes away some of the humidity on the window in order to look outside -- but there's no way to a thing out there. So the Pilot gets up -- moves toward the broken window covered with LEAVES and BRANCHES --

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -- I wouldn't do that.

dialogues.speaker: PILOT
dialogues.text: -- Good to know. And the Pilot puts the transceiver down on his seat as he pushes away the LEAVES and BRANCHES and PEEKS HIS HEAD OU THE SHATTERED WINDOW. Jack and Kate watch, terrified for a moment. Then, quietl

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: «-.-DO you s--

dialogues.speaker: DROPS THE TRANSCEIVER ONTO THE FLOOR AND HE SCREAMS
dialogues.text: BLOODYFUCKINGMURDER AS JACK MOVES TO HOLD KATE BACK -—

dialogues.speaker: FINALLY GETS YANKED OUT OF THE COCKPIT AND SUDDENLY THE T
dialogues.text: QUTSIDE SLAMS INTO THE SIDE OF THE COCKPIT -— (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  81 82 83 84 43.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jack, Kate and Charlie all on the ground, scrambling to g out, trying to get the fuck out of the cockpit but -- Jack looks back -- sees the TRANSCEIVER has fallen off th pilot's seat. He reaches for it -- BAM! The cockpit jars again -- transceiver skitters out of Jack's grasp --

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: No... But he doesn't give up -- lunges after it -- SLAM! Jack loses his footing, lands on his stomach -- transceiver's sitting there, arm's length away and -- Jack finally gets it into his grasp -- staggering to his as it SHIFTS again and -- BAM!!! ONCE ~~ THE THREE FALL DOWN -— TWICE -~ AND THEN AGAIN -— AND THE WHOLE COCKPIT DROPS -—-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- The giant piece of jet CRASHES to the ground -- we're TIGHT so that we don't see the BEAST that's done it -- bu now it makes a HORRIBLY LOUD CRY -- INT. FRONT SECTION OF THE PLANE - COCKPIT - RAINSTORM — 8

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUOUS
dialogues.text: -- And it's so LOUD in here. Jack scrambles after Kate an Charlie, all three trying to get the fuck outta here -- EXT. FRONT SECTION OF THE PLANE - RAINSTORM — CONTINUOUS -- And they do -- and they're RUNNING IN THE RAIN LIKE CR -- another LOUD STEP and as we're TRACKING AT HIGH SPEED THROUGH THE RAIN -- WE WHIP PAN TO A SPRINTING KATE -— And we INTERCUT NOW between KATE, JACK AND CHARLIE -- ALL RUNNING LIKE NUTS -—

dialogues.speaker: MROOQOOOWRRRRRRRRROQQOQQOOQOQOOOBWWRRRRRRRRRRRRR
dialogues.text: Christ, it's close -- THE SOUND is all around us now, no if we're running toward it or away from it, just PURE FUC FEAR AND CONFUSION and... Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.text: Runs through THICK TANGLED ROOTS and WIPES OUT -- coming HARD -- WIND knocked out of him -- he tries to get up but CAN'T -- suddenly JACK is there to help him up --

dialogues.speaker: C'MON
dialogues.text: But Charlie's foot is caught and the fucking THING is COM -- LOUDER AND LOUDER and that's when we CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: KATE 87
dialogues.text: Still running, up ahead -- CRYING as she runs through the rain -- almost losing her footing, but not -- distant SCR OVERWHELMED by a THUNDERCLAP and Kate SCREAMS as she runs

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: But when the THUNDER stops, the screaming is gone -- and runs and runs and finally SLIPS -- FALLS HARD -- scramble her feet and takes SHELTER inside:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Kate's hiding now, in the ALIEN BRANCHES AND VINES of FOOT-TALL TREE. She waits there... and waits... TERRIFIED and we just HOLD ON HER... AND HOLD... until she SCREAMS

dialogues.text: -- But there's nothing -- no one -- and she waits... her GLUED TO THE DIRECTION THEY JUST CAME FROM... she breathe heavily, waiting... and WE HOLD ON HER FOR ALMOST A MINUT And as soon as we get so close we couldn't possibly get a closer -- she whispers to herself, terrified:

dialogues.text: One... two... three... four... CUT TO BLACK.
