dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kate is exactly where we left her, tucked amongst the roo of the alien tree. Rain pouring down around her. Dark in here. She's scared to death. We're with her. CLOSE. And she hears a SOUND over the rain -- something moving towards her -- and she turns around -- looking behind her now, petrified. Nothing there. Her eyes wide, blinking in the rain. Nothi but jungle. She then turns back -- AND CHARLIE IS STANDING RIGHT THER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and it scares her so much she SCREAMS AND GRABS HIM -- PUSHING -- AND THEY FALL OVER onto his back, her lying on of him in the mud --

dialogues.speaker: KATE CHARLIE
dialogues.text: WHERE THE HELL'S JACK?! -- I don't know! -- Yes! He helped me up--! -- So where is he?! -- I don't know where he--!

dialogues.speaker: -- HOW COULD YOU NOT KNOW
dialogues.text: -- and Kate stops long enough for Charlie to say:

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: -- he pulled me up. If he hadn't, that th--

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: -- Did you see it?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No. No. But it was right behind us. We were dead -- I was. Until Jack came back for me. And just then, something remarkable happens. The rain sto As abruptly as it started, it's gone. They both look back the way they came -- Kate looking up, Charlie, still on h back, craning his head.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: We have to go back for him.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Go back? There? Love -- listen -- there's a certain... gargantuan quality to whatever the hell that thing is -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  46.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She's already getting up:

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: -- Then don't come. And she goes off, after Jack. Pissed and nervous, Charlie finally goes after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOLLY OUT OF THE THICK FOLIAGE to find Kate and Charlie, walking slowly through the dripping-wet jungle, back the they came. They're edgy... and we're moving with them. Th DRIPPING SOUNDS somehow unnerving. Then Kate sees something up ahead. Something GLISTENING i the mud -- and she moves for it, Charlie behind her. And she gets to it -- kneels -- it's a scattered collecti of COINS. And among them, something she picks up. A PILOT'S WINGS PIN. And Kate stares at the pin, horrified... because she sens what's coming next. She SLOWLY LOOKS UP. And sees somethi horrific. Charlie looks up too. His mouth opens in shock.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: ..-What the hell's that...? Then, a welcome voice:

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It's the pilot. And they turn around -- grateful to see Jack approaching the jungle -- Kate moves to him, scared --

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: -- Did you see it?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: No. It was right behind me, I dove into the bushes. Charlie's eyes have gone back to the tree.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: ...Excuse me, people... but... how the hell does something like that happen...? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  47.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: And they all look up again... and we FOLLOW THEIR GAZE to reveal that, stuck up in a branch, at least thirty-five f above ground -- IS THE BLOODY, TORN BODY OF THE PILOT. De

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: now, for sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHANNON, wearing a BIKINI now, lying near the surf. Of al things, she's SUNBATHING. And the glorious sun is doing i job -- and it's a damn Coppertone commercial -- except as camera SLOWLY DOLLIES, the huge PLANE WRECK is revealed i the distance. And we can see, in the background, the Survivors are goin through luggage, doing work to get a fire burning again, laying clothing out to dry. And after a beat, Boone walks over, looking down at his vacationing sister.

dialogues.speaker: BOONE
dialogues.text: Hey, we're going through the clothes. Sorting them. (beat, judgemental) I see you found your bag. (beat) You wanna give us a hand?

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON
dialogues.text: (doesn't even look) Not really. Boone just stares at her, absolutely despising her. But a he does is turn and walk off. HOLD ON SHANNON for a beat...until we HEAR:

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Is that your boyfriend? And Shannon looks over: Claire sits twenty some feet away Shannon's far nicer to Claire than Boone.

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON
dialogues.text: (with vitriol) My brother. Boone. God's friggin' gift to humanity. A beat. Then Shannon turns to Claire -- actually very swe

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you know what it is? A beat for Claire (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  48.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: Not yet. (beat, quietly, half to herself) .--I haven't felt the baby kick since yesterday. And Shannon turns to her -- off her look we CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: SEA URCHIN 92
dialogues.text: As it's picked out of a tidal pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the surf line, Jin, our Korean HUSBAND, his pants roll up, intensely picks SEA URCHINS from the water, placing t in a PLASTIC BAG he's taken from the plane. It's an oddly serene image. And then we have a REVERSE VIEW -- from the ocean inland and Sun, Jin's wife, sits on the sand. Sitting, straight backed, rather stoic. Watching her husband. The TOP BUTTO of her blouse undone. Then we're TIGHT on Sun's face as she watches him, his ba to her... and though there's no dialogue here, there does need to be. Because her gaze is distinctly unsettled.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Excuse me. And Sun looks up. Michael stands there.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have you seen my boy? Sun just looks at Michael for a long beat. Finally, she speaks, in her native language:

dialogues.speaker: SUN
dialogues.text: (in KOREAN) My apologies... but I do not speak English. And Michael stands there for a moment, confused. And Mich looks up and sees that, mid-reach into the sea, Jin has stopped working, looking back at her wife and this strang man. Which should tell us immediately how controlling Jin really is. Then, Jin calls out: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  49.

dialogues.speaker: JIN
dialogues.text: (in KOREAN) Your top button is undone! Button it, please, right now! And Michael watches, somewhat fascinated and disturbed as buttons it up. Michael then says, quietly:

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: ...I'm, uh... I'm sorry... And Michael walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're maybe two feet off the ground, DOLLYING through the jungle. And we HEAR:

dialogues.speaker: WALT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Vincent! (beat) Vincent! And Walt enters the FOREGROUND -- so close that all we se his waist to his knees -- and that he's holding a DOG LEA He stops.

dialogues.speaker: WALT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Vincent! And we BOOM UP as Walt turns, looking off-camera, his eye scanning the jungle. Then he sees something... and he wal toward it -- and we FOLLOW HIM, over his shoulder, BOOMIN as he arrive at the shiny piece of metal lying on the lea floor. He picks it up. IT'S A PAIR OF HANDCUFFS. And Walt holds them. TIGHT ON HIM as he looks at them, deeply curious. Just then he HEARS:

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey! And Walt turns as Michael approaches, kneeling, taking th kid firmly by the shoulders: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  50.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -- What did I tell you? -- I thought maybe Vincent -- After everything that's would be around -- happened -- I told you to stay on the -- I didn't go far, this is beach. so close to the beach, I -- No, don't do this -- you thought this would be okay -- listen to me, I mean what I say. You understand that? (then, seeing them) ...What’s this?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: ...I just found' em. PUSH IN on Michael, disturbed, as he considers the existe of these cuffs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, Kate and Charlie walking back. A pregnant SILENCE. All of them still in the wake of the insanity of what jus happened. Jack up front, fiddling with the transceiver.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Anything?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (not happy) ..-You keep asking me if there's anything.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Pardon me for appearing desperate, but in case you didn't hear the pilot before he was eaten, they're never going to find us unless we get that thing to work. (deep breath, then) So is there anything?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: What were you doing. In the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Oh, I thought you could tell. I was getting sick. Puking. My one... tangible contribution to this trek.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: No, I'm glad you came. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  51.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, every trek needs a coward.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: You're not a coward. And as they walk we're TIGHT ON CHARLIE, who considers th as they walk... and we HOLD TIGHT ON HIS FACE AS SOUNDS F

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Are you all right, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back on the PLANE, PRE-CRASH. CHARLIE sits in his seat ne the rear of the plane, shaking. Pale. SWEAT dots his brow He looks up at the same FLIGHT ATTENDANT that helped Jack

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah -- I'm good, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Can I get you some wat--?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (go away) I'm fine. Thank you. Please. The Flight Attendant stares. Then:

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: All right. As she heads to the back of the plane, she looks at him, maybe a little SUSPICIOUSLY. Charlie taps his hand, FIDGETY. Takes a quick peek over h shoulder at --

dialogues.speaker: THE REAR GALLEY
dialogues.text: The Flight Attendant who he just blew off talks to TWO MA FLIGHT ATTENDANTS in hushed tones and -- All three look up at Charlie. He immediately faces front -- nervous. TIGHT on him. He turns back -- takes another peek -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  52.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ALL THREE FLIGHT ATTENDANTS are heading back up the aisle towards him -- Charlie quickly undoes his seatbelt, gets up in one swift motion --

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Sir? Excuse me -- But Charlie's already moving fast down the aisle -- and h brushes by JACK, getting up from his own seat --

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Sorry... And as Charlie moves on, we can just hear behind him --

dialogues.speaker: ROSE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Guess he really had to go. Charlie arrives at the lavatories -- but they're both occupied.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: -- Bugger -—- -- And so he KEEPS MOVING, through BUSINESS CLASS -- cros to the other side of the plane -- he keeps going, into FI CLASS -- he turns back to see the THREE FLIGHT ATTENDANTS heading for him -- and the PLANE SHAKES. Just a little. N big deal. DING -- "FASTEN SEATBELTS" LIGHTS UP as Charlie reaches the FRONT LAVATORY, enters --

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT ATTENDANT'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentleman, the pilot has turned on the fasten seatbelts sign -- please return to your seats with your seatbelts fastened...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie is FLIPPING OUT. CAMERA is in here with him, TIGH CLAUSTROPHOBIC as he PULLS OFF HIS SHOE -- reaches into h SOCK as suddenly there's a KNOCK ON THE DOOR --

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Sir? Are you all right? Charlie ignores her, still digging in his sock... finally pulls out a ROLLED UP BAGGIE containing a BROWN POWDER. KNOCKING MORE INSISTENT NOW... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  97 98 99 10 53.

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Sir, I'm going to have to ask you to open the door... Charlie holds the baggie up... looks at it longingly. Thi physically PAINS him. But he turns around and drops it in the TOILET. The baggie rests on the METAL DROP-PLATE as..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (firm) Open the door now, sir. Charlie takes one last look at his stash, TIGHT SHOT as h reaches for the FLUSH LEVER and...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: FALLS out of the bathroom -- and in the TERRIFYING JOLTS the last minutes of the flight, he falls back to --

dialogues.speaker: FIRST CLASS 100
dialogues.text: -- FALLS to the floor and CRAWLS back through the MASSIVE PANDEMONIUM -- gets into a free chair -- BUCKLES UP and w TIGHT on his TERRIFIED EYES as we: CUT TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: END ACT FOUR
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  54.

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: 101 EXT. “BASE CAMP” - CRASH SITE - DAY 101 CHAOS. We drop right into the middle of a BRAWL. CLOSE ON THE FIGHT as Sawyer and Sayid WRESTLE. It’s PANDEMONIUM. A GROUP of twenty or so stands around, watch the brutal fight --

dialogues.speaker: ...GONNA KILL YOU... LET HIM GO
dialogues.text: OF... DON’T!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ACROSS THE CAMP Jack, Kate and Charlie emerge from the jungle, see all this --

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: What -- ? But Jack is already pulling his pack off, immediately ent the fray, pulling the men apart --

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: -- All right, ENOUGH!

dialogues.speaker: SAYID SAWYER
dialogues.text: I’ve had enough of this guy! You've had enough of me?! If You_accuse me of being a the shoe fits, buddy! Look criminal?! What next? I around! They all know it’s suppose you think I am you! I’m just the only one responsible for the crash! SAYING it!

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: HEY! What the hell --? Michael is here, holds up the pair of CUFFS --

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: My kid found these out in the jungle. On Jack. Kate. Charlie. All digesting this as...

dialogues.speaker: SAWYER
dialogues.text: (finger in Sayid’s face) And this guy was in the back row of business class the whole flight. Never got up. Hands folded under his blanket. And for some crazy reason -- I’m just pointing this out -- the guy I saw next to him didn’t make it. Do the math -- (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  101 55.

dialogues.speaker: SAWYER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (nose to nose with Sayid) You're the prisoner, muchacho.

dialogues.speaker: SAYID SAWYER
dialogues.text: Thank you so much for observing my behavior so very carefully -- You think I didn’t see them pull you out of line before -- If you do not take your we boarded? finger out of my face -- -- Oh, please -- bring it-- And they’re about to go at it all over again when --

dialogues.speaker: STOP
dialogues.text: And they do. All eyes on Kate. Strong. Defiant. Angry.

dialogues.speaker: KATE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We actually DO have bigger problems than this. (beat, pulls the TRANSCEIVER from Jack's pack) We found the transceiver. But it’s not working. Can anybody help...? A beat. Then, of all people, Sayid steps forward. Turns back, looks directly at fuckin’ Sawyer.

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: Yes, I might be able to.

dialogues.speaker: SAWYER
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, good! This guy! Perfect! Let’s trust him -- !

dialogues.speaker: HURLEY
dialogues.text: Hey -- we’re all in this together, man. Let's try to treat each other with --

dialogues.speaker: SAWYER
dialogues.text: Shut up, lardo.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: HEY -- Give it a break.

dialogues.speaker: SAWYER
dialogues.text: (fuck you) Whatever you say, Doc, you're the hero. And Sawyer walks off, passing Jack, BUMPING him as he goe Jack watches him, not liking him one bit -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  101 102 103 56.

dialogues.speaker: BOONE
dialogues.text: You found the cockpit? Were there any survivors? Kate and Charlie exchange a look. Turn their eyes to Jack who meets their gaze. A beat. Then:

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: (re: transceiver) It’s dual-band. Military spec. Broadcasts full-range, far as I can tell. Chances are the battery is good, but the radio... it is dead.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: -- Can you get it to work?

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: (stares at it, feels pressure) I need some time. Kate nods -- Sayid walks off -- just as Rose moves to Jac saying quietly:

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: That man with the metal in his side -- he looks bad. Takes a beat for Jack to hear this -- but he finally does Jack looks at Kate for a moment -- then heads off. HOLD O Kate, who stands there, alone.

dialogues.speaker: TRANSCEIVER
dialogues.text: The broken transceiver, being OPENED. We are:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sayid’s right at the edge of the fuselage, sitting on wreckage, using TWEEZERS and a found SWISS ARMY KNIFE to apart and examine the transceiver. Checking the internal connections. After a beat, Hurley arrives, sitting across from him. Saying one word, the sub-text being, “What a fucking pric

dialogues.speaker: HURLEY
dialogues.text: (re: Sawyer) That chain-smoking jackass. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  57.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sayid glances up, nods: no kidding, then goes back to the radio. Understatement of the day:

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: Some people have problems.

dialogues.speaker: HURLEY
dialogues.text: Some people have problems. (then) Us. Him.

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: (amused) Us him. Hurley smiles back. Then:

dialogues.speaker: HURLEY
dialogues.text: You're okay. I like you.

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: (considers Hurley) You're okay, too.

dialogues.speaker: HURLEY
dialogues.text: Hurley.

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: Sayid. As Sayid works:

dialogues.speaker: HURLEY
dialogues.text: How d’you know how to do all that?

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: I was a Military Communications Officer.

dialogues.speaker: HURLEY
dialogues.text: Yeah? (then) Y’ever see battle?

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: Oh yes. (then) I fought in the Gulf War.

dialogues.speaker: HURLEY
dialogues.text: No way. I have a buddy, fought over there. He was in the 104th Airborne. Where you in the Air Force? Army? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  103 104 105 58.

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: (looks at him) The Republican Guard. And Hurley looks at him... realizing that holy shit... he just bonded with the enemy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG LENS, CLOSE ON KATE, standing alone in a lagoon, out sight of the others. Her duffel bag on the shore, she wea only her underwear and tank-top in the water, cleaning herself off, using a shirt as washcloth. As she does this, she CRIES. Letting out all of the emoti that’s been building. We HOLD on her. This moment a catharsis for us as well. And we HOLD on her long enough to see her pull it togethe Finding her strength again. Staring off, knowing that somehow she has to keep moving forward.

dialogues.speaker: SUN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (in KOREAN) -- Excuse me -- -- And Kate turns to see Sun standing there -- and Sun is slightly embarrassed as she points back, toward the wreck SUN (CONT’D) (in KOREAN) -- I believe they are finished. They need you. And Sun moves away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kate returns, dressed now -- as Sayid finishes wrapping t radio in black electrical tape.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: -- Is it working?

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: Seems to be -- except we’re not picking up a signal.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: -- Why would we need to pick up a signal, aren’t we sending one -- ? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  105

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: And Sayid Currently, 59. 105

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: -- Yes, but it’s a “transceiver” -- it transmits and receives. Which means you can also read the level of other signals that you are picking up. (shows her) What you want is to see little bars. Right here. shows her where RECEPTION BARS would normally be. there are none.

dialogues.speaker: SAYID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The little bars would show that the radio is getting reception. Meaning we'd be in range of another radio. There are no bars here.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: ...So the radio’s worthless.

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: -- We could broadcast blind. Hope that someone... maybe a ship, somewhere, picks up our distress call. But that would be a waste of the battery. Which might not last for long.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: We need the bars.

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: We need the bars. (then, with a thought) It is unlikely, but perhaps worth a try.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: -- What.

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: Sending a signal from high ground.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (uh-oh) .+-How high? And Sayid’s eyes flick over Kate’s shoulder as... Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  60.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Following Sayid’s gaze. And CAMERA SLOWLY FOLLOWS KATE HE AS SHE TURNS, REVEALING -- the ENORMOUS MOUNTAINS that ho above them. Scary high. And with the next part of their mission now before them... CUT TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: END ACT FIVE
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca
Jack examines SHRAPNEL MAN. His condition has worsened considerably -- skin taking on a yellow hue. Shallow breaths. As Jack delicately looks at the wound --

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: How is he? Jack glances over his shoulder, sees Kate. Eyes go Shrapnel Man. Shakes his head: not good. And she caring, nervous for the Man:

dialogues.speaker: KATE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .»+.-Can you do anything?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I can pull out the shrapnel.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: ...-But yesterday you said --

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: -- I know. But that was yesterday. (then) I was hoping he’d be at a hospital by now. (beat) We leave him like this... he’ll be dead within a day. If I open him up... and if I can control the bleeding... and if he doesn’t go into sepsis -- and if I can find some antibiotics... he might be all right. But there’s no way of knowing until I see what kind of damage there is in there. (sees she’s freaked; a morose joke) Hey -- at least he’s unconscious. Kate absorbs this. A lot going on behind her eyes. almost see her make a decision. Then --

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I’m going on a hike.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Sorry? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca 107 back to asks, We can (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: y.com/library  62.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: We fixed the transceiver, but we can’t use it, not from here. If I --

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: -- Kate -- wait a second --

dialogues.speaker: KATE JACK
dialogues.text: You’re the one who said we had to get out a signal -- -- Yeah, and we do, but I -- Someone has to -- and it don’t want you going in can’t be you, not with what there. he needs -- -- I want you to wait for me - -- No -- = -- There’s not time -- we -- Kate -- obviously need to send out a signal sooner than later -- -- Hold on a second -- you -- Yes I did, what makes you Saw what that thing did to think you’re any safer on the the pilot -- beach than you are in the jungle? Well. That’s logic that even Jack can’t argue with. He looks at Shrapnel man, knowing he has to stay --

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wait for me. I don’t know how long this‘1l take --

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Sayid says the battery won’t last. Jack looks at her. Knows he can’t stop her.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: If you hear anything. Anything. (beat) Run.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: You know I will.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Good luck. Kate throws another look at Shrapnel Man -- intense. Connected. Somehow doesn’t want to leave him. Then:

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: You too. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  108 109 110 63.

dialogues.speaker: SEA URCHIN
dialogues.text: The sea urchin gets CUT with a found POCKET KNIFE. REVEAL that we are:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the shore. Sun kneels on the sand, cutting the sea urchins for food prep on a large ROCK. Jin stands beside her, holding an airplane FOOD TRAY, collecting the cut pieces. Once she's done, Jin takes the newly-cut pieces and adds to the tray. Sun reaches to take one of the pieces off the rock -- cle just trying to help -- but Jin actually slaps her hand, putting the piece onto the tray himself. She reacts -- obedient and accepting as Jin walks off with the tray. TI ON SUN as she watches him go. And in a private moment of defiance -- her eyes holding o her husband as he walks off -- SHE UNDOES THE TOP BUTTON HER _ BLOUSE. A WIDE SHOT of the image -- the complicated couple with t culturally-formed dynamic framed majestically by the incredible tropical terrain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurley stands in the water, cleaning one of his shirts. After a long beat, Jin approaches with the tray. When Jin speaks, it's terse. Seemingly cold. And, of course, not i English:

dialogues.speaker: JIN
dialogues.text: (in KOREAN) I have food. Here. Try this. Hurley turns, sees Jin.

dialogues.speaker: HURLEY
dialogues.text: S'up.

dialogues.speaker: JIN
dialogues.text: (in KOREAN) Try this. Sea urchin, it's good, it'll keep you alive. Hurley takes a beat to understand what he's suggesting. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  110 111 112 64.

dialogues.speaker: HURLEY
dialogues.text: -- What. That? What, eat that?

dialogues.speaker: JIN
dialogues.text: (in KOREAN) It's food, there's enough for everybody.

dialogues.speaker: HURLEY
dialogues.text: Dude, guess what, I'm starving. But I am not nearly that hungry. No. (slow, louder) Thank you. No way. No. And Hurley turns back. Jin, finally realizing he's being rejected, walks off.

dialogues.speaker: COMIC BOOK
dialogues.text: A page turns. It's THE FLASH. The text -- all dialog balloons, everything -- are in SPANISH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walt lies here, reading. Angry. Vincent's LEASH nearby. H turns the page. After a beat, Michael comes. Lies beside him. Eyes the comic. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: ..-That comic's in Spanish. (beat, knowing) «--D'you... read Spanish--?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: No. (then) I found it. Michael just nods. Nothing's working. Takes a moment.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Esta ese libro bueno, pequefio hombre? (nothing from Walt) That was... I was kidding. (beat) Tell me about your school -- you go to school?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Yeah, I go to school.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: ...Though maybe ‘cause you travelled so much that y-- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  112 113 65.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: I go to school. A beat. Nothing's working. Then:

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Tell you what. When we get home... I'll get you another dog. And Walt looks back at his father. These words have the opposite of their intended effect -- they tell the kid th his dog is dead. And furious -- on the verge of tears -- Walt gets up and heads off. Michael watches him go, his e closing. Somehow he's fucked it up again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sayid puts the TRANSCEIVER in a plastic bag, then wraps i a beach towel. Nearby, Kate fills an empty water bottle w RAIN WATER collected on the TARP. She seems determined he Driven.

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: The others. They've heard about the thing you saw. The pilot. (off Kate's surprise) I understand why you and the doctor decided not to frighten us, but your English friend is telling anyone who will listen. (beat; grim) They think we are insane for going back in there. Kate hesitates. Then --

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: If he told you about the pilot, he told you what the pilot said. The rescue people -- they're looking in the wrong place. They're not gonna find us. Sayid nods. But his eyes stay on her. Curious --

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: I don't like it here. But you... you don't like it here even more than I do. (off her look) I agree, sending a signal from high ground -- this is something we need to do. (beat) But your... willingness to go back in. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  113 114 115 116 66.

dialogues.speaker: SAYID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: After you saw... whatever it is you saw. It is either impressive. Brave. Or something else... I can't really understand. Sayid's looking at her now -- with those deep eyes -- alm as if looking into her soul... and God, it unnerves her.

dialogues.speaker: BAGGIE
dialogues.text: A hand unrolls a sandwich bag containing an ounce of BROW POWDER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the crash site in the distance, Charlie -- sweating, slightly shaking -- has found some privacy here. And good thing: Charlie takes a pinky nail-full of the powder and SNORTS it. We're TIGHT ON HIM as we watch its effects: Charlie calms "evens out" almost instantly. He closes the bag, rolls it -- feeling much better about himself now --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT ON THE FACE OF A MALE FLIGHT ATTENDANT. Lying DEAD, eyes open, facing us. SLOWLY DOLLY and RACK FOCUS TO REVE SHANNON, sitting a few feet away in the sand. She stares the corpse, hugging her knees, quiet and nervous. The first dead body she's ever seen. And she just stares the thing, until Boone slowly walks up behind her. A beat

dialogues.speaker: BOONE
dialogues.text: ..»-What the hell are you doing. She just stares. Then, quietly:

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON
dialogues.text: ...I think I was mean to him.

dialogues.speaker: BOONE
dialogues.text: (beat) ..-What?

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON
dialogues.text: He was the guy.

dialogues.speaker: BOONE
dialogues.text: What guy? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  67.

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON
dialogues.text: The guy at the gate. The guy who wouldn't give us our seats. (beat) In first class. Finally she looks at Boone.

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Remember him? And Boone's staring. Christ, he does remember. Her eyes g back to the body. Realizing, she says, sotto:

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He saved our lives. This morbid moment makes Boone very uncomfortable:

dialogues.speaker: BOONE
dialogues.text: Shannon, come on, we're trying to clear the wreckage why don't you help out. But she doesn't turn away.

dialogues.speaker: BOONE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on, you're being worthless over here. That makes her turn to him, hurt, pissed off:

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON
dialogues.text: .--I'm being what?

dialogues.speaker: BOONE
dialogues.text: -- Well come on, you're sitting on your ass staring at bodies -- that isn't--

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON
dialogues.text: Hey, I've been through a trauma, okay--?!

dialogues.speaker: BOONE
dialogues.text: -- We've all been through a trauma! The difference is that since the crash you've actually given yourself a pedicure! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON
dialogues.text: You know what? It's so easy to make fun of me -- and you're good at it, I get it -- well screw you -- you don't know the first thing about what I'm thinking -- -- No you don't! 68. 116

dialogues.speaker: BOONE
dialogues.text: -- I'd rather not waste my time making fun of you! I wish I didn't have any reason to! Yeah, it is easy! I have a better idea than you think I do -- -- No? Okay, Shannon, what are you thinking?
As Shannon's eyes flick over Boone's shoulder -- and we R FOCUS past Boone to the distance, where Kate and Sayid pa up to go.

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON
dialogues.text: I'm going with them. On the hike. A beat. Then -- Boone just laughs.

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm going.

dialogues.speaker: BOONE
dialogues.text: Oh yeah?

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON
dialogues.text: (fuck you) Yup. She grabs her WINDBREAKER, walks past an incredulous Boon

dialogues.speaker: BOONE
dialogues.text: -- No you're not. (she doesn't stop.) Shannon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Kate and Sayid finish ZIPPING PACKS as Shannon, then Boone, arrive --

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON
dialogues.text: I'd like to come with you.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Thanks, but we're -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  118 69.

dialogues.speaker: BOONE SHANNON
dialogues.text: She's not going. (sharp, to Boone) (to Kate et al) -- The hell I'm not -- -- She doesn't want to go -- she does this -- -- You don't know what the hell I "do"!

dialogues.speaker: BOONE
dialogues.text: She postures -- makes choices just to infuriate her family-- which at the moment is me --

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON
dialogues.text: Shut-up and stop trying to be charming-- (to Kate, et al) I'm coming with you.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I'm not sure that's a good idea --

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON
dialogues.text: What're you -- like, two years older than me? Please. (turns to Charlie, who arrives) You're going, right?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: -- Where, on the hike? Are you?

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON
dialogues.text: Yup.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: -- Yes, I'm going. Definitely.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (firm, no time) Look, everybody can come. (heaves her PACK onto her back) But we're leaving now. And Kate walks off. Shannon looks to Charlie, slightly ta aback by Kate. Says quietly:

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You couldn't tell from that, but she's quite nice, really. Shannon heads off. Boone, annoyed, follows. Then Charlie and Sayid. A LONG SHOT of them walking off -- then PULL BACK TO REVE we're with: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  119 120 70.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sawyer watches them go as he sits on part of the shattere wing, near the remains of one of the enormous engines. He taking final drags on a cig. In general, a "fuck 'em all" attitude. After a beat, something weighing on his mind, he pulls hi wallet from a back pocket. Opens it. Pulls out a folded piece of paper. Unfolds it. TIGHT on Sawyer's face as he re-reads the page. And slowly... his face changes. His eyes awash in concern and, more surprisingly, vulnerability. He just stares at mysterious letter... his eyes actually WELLING UP with wh he reads. Finally, quickly, he re-folds it -- puts it back in his wallet, more anxious and troubled than we've seen him. He finishes the cigarette and puts it out on the damn airplane that brought him here. He gets up and moves off, quickly, after the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Kate, with Sayid at the head of the group. Charlie, Shannon and Boone behind her in that order. They're just entering the jungle -- the growth gets thick quickly. And now we CUT BACK TO SAWYER, who moves quickly, determi through the jungle -- passing Boone, Charlie, Shannon -- Sayid and KATE, who he looks at, walking with her for a moment. Their eyes lock. She's surprised -- and not pleased.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Decided to join us?

dialogues.speaker: SAWYER
dialogues.text: Yeah, looks like it.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: What changed your mind?

dialogues.speaker: SAWYER
dialogues.text: (mind your own business) I'm a complex guy, Sweetheart. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  71.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: And Sawyer keeps walking, taking the lead. Kate wanting t tell him off -- but not. And we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDE SHOT. Spectacular view. Our SIX HIKERS (Kate, Sayid, Charlie, Shannon and Boone, with Sawyer at the front, hac away plants with a found stick) trudge through the jungle the base of the MOUNTAIN. The hike isn't any fun. Plus, it's HOT. Also, they're scared. Kate especially -- lookin around with concern as they walk. Afraid that, at any moment, that Thing might show up to end their lives. Now WE FAVOR Shannon and Charlie, who walks beside her:

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Y'ever heard of Drive Shaft?

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON
dialogues.text: ..-What, the band?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON
dialogues.text: (not a fan) Yuchhh.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Nothing. Horrible.

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON
dialogues.text: Do you have one of their songs stuck in your head--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: -- Uh, yeah, sort of--

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON
dialogues.text: -- God, I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (laughs it off, dying) Yeah. Me too. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  122 123 124 72.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back near the fuselage, Jack approaches Hurley --

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I need some help.

dialogues.speaker: HURLEY
dialogues.text: -- Okay --

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I need you to help me go through the luggage -- I need any prescription medication you can find -- especially any drugs that end with "mycin" or "cillin"-- those are antibiotics--

dialogues.speaker: HURLEY
dialogues.text: -- What's this for?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Please just do it -- you'll see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT ON A SHAVING KIT. Jack's hands UNZIP it. Pulls out DISPOSABLE RAZOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, disappointed, puts the shaving kit back in the bag he TURNS, opens another bag. And he notices MICHAEL, sitt nearby among the bags, staring off. As Jack goes through another bag, he asks:

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: ..-How's your son? Michael looks up, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Walt? Yeah, I think he'll be all right.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: How old is he?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Nine. (then, suddenly) Ten. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  124 125 126 73.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jack glances at Michael, then finds something in the lugg It's another SHAVING KIT. As he UNZIPS it, starts to go through the contents --

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Walt's more worried about his dog than anything. It was on the plane, so... Kids, you know. They're --

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: -- Was it a white lab?

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (stunned) ...Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: -- Yeah, I saw him yesterday. In the jungle.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: -- What? Where?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Over there, hundred yards in or so. He looked good. And Jack pulls out a STRAIGHT RAZOR. He snaps open the blade. Tests its sharpness with his finger.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: -- What was that thing you saw. In the jungle -- what was it? Jack folds the razor shut.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I have no idea. And Jack walks off. Michael looks toward the jungle. Sigh burdened with a task he doesn't want to accept: going int the jungle after that damn dog.

dialogues.speaker: BACKGAMMON SET 125
dialogues.text: EXTREME CLOSEUP of a mini-travel MAGNETIC BACKGAMMON SET. Hands setting up the pieces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Locke, setting up the game. After a long beat, ina WIDE SHOT, Walt comes into frame, watching Locke. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  126 74.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A long beat of silence. Finally, Locke asks, without ever looking up:

dialogues.speaker: LOCKE
dialogues.text: Do you play? A beat.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Nope. (long beat) -..-What is it? Is it like Checkers? As odd as Locke seemed around the adults, he almost seems normal now. A bizarre child-like honesty that makes him accessible to Walt.

dialogues.speaker: LOCKE
dialogues.text: Not really. (looks up) It's a better game than Checkers. And after a beat, Walt moves closer to Locke. Watches.

dialogues.speaker: LOCKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you play checkers with your pop?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: (long beat) No. (beat) I was in Australia with my mom.

dialogues.speaker: LOCKE
dialogues.text: You have no accent.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Yeah, we move a lot. (beat) She got sick. She died. So. Locke looks at the kid. You sorta wish he weren't.

dialogues.speaker: LOCKE
dialogues.text: You're having a rough month. Matter of fact. Not talking down to the kid. And Walt appreciates that. Locke turns his attention back to the board. Slowly and gently continues to set up the board, pushing the small black and white tiles onto their starti points. The effect is almost mesmerizing -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  126 75.

dialogues.speaker: LOCKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Backgammon is the oldest game in the world. Much older than chess. Archaeologists found sets when they excavated the ruins of Ancient Mesopotamia. Would you like to guess how old they were?

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: A hundred years?

dialogues.speaker: LOCKE
dialogues.text: Five thousand years.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: (whispers to himself) ...Five thousand...

dialogues.speaker: LOCKE
dialogues.text: ...That's older than Jesus Christ. Which doesn't really land for Walt. But he asks:

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: Did they have dice and stuff?

dialogues.speaker: LOCKE
dialogues.text: Yes. But theirs weren't made of plastic. (then) Their dice were made of bones.

dialogues.speaker: WALT
dialogues.text: (slightly nervous) Cool. Walt watches carefully as Locke picks up one WHITE piece one BLACK one. Folds them into his CLASPED hands and gent shakes...

dialogues.speaker: LOCKE
dialogues.text: The Persians called it "Takhteh Nard" which means "Battle on Wood". Two players. Two sides. One is light. One is dark. Locke extends his closed fists, offering them to Walt. Wa considers... deliberates. Then taps his finger on Locke's right hand. He slowly opens one. We don't get to see it, Walt does. And now that distracted creepy grin is back. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  126 127 76.

dialogues.speaker: LOCKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Walt. (beat, sotto) ...You wanna know a secret? HOLD ON the boy, staring at him... intrigued...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back at the beach, Claire sits in the First Class seat, writing in a journal. Sad. Scared. And after a beat, Jin is there, with a tray of sea urchins. She regards the plate.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: ».-.-Oh. No thank you. But Jin insists:

dialogues.speaker: JIN
dialogues.text: (in KOREAN) You will need to eat -- especially you, you should have some. She hesitates, but takes some. Chews some off. Eats it. And God, does she not like it. Jin watches her, nodding:

dialogues.speaker: JIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (in KOREAN) It's good, isn't it? And as she eats the horrible food, suddenly her face chan Like she just felt something. Jin looks on, concerned -- and Claire stands --

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: -- Oh my God --

dialogues.speaker: JIN
dialogues.text: (in KOREAN) -- What is it? Are you -- are you okay? And she suddenly SMILES -- beams -- THANK GOD, SHE'S FELT

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE
dialogues.text: -- I felt it! Come here -- feel this! -- And she takes Jin's hand -- which disturbs him to no e he doesn't like this situation at all -- especially what

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: does: PLACING HIS HAND ON HER BELLY --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  127 128 77.

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -- Do you feel that?! Feel (in KOREAN) that! It's a kick! That's a -- Excuse me, that's okay, I foot! Right there -- no don't need to -- I would wait, it's moving -- he's rather not -- no, that's all moving around -- he... I right, please let go of my guess I think it's a he... hand -- And Claire's laughing now at the relief -- her eyes teari up as she talks to her belly:

dialogues.speaker: CLAIRE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I felt you -- thank you -- thank you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another WIDE SHOT. Different area, some time later. And o GROUP arrives, hiking through. As they do:

dialogues.speaker: SAWYER
dialogues.text: Okay. Wide open space. (to Sayid) You should check the radio -- see if we're good.

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: We're not gonna have any reception yet --

dialogues.speaker: SAWYER
dialogues.text: -- Tell you what -- just try it.

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: I don't want to waste the batteries --

dialogues.speaker: SAWYER
dialogues.text: -- I'm not asking you to keep it on all day --

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: -- We're still blocked by the mountain --

dialogues.speaker: SAWYER
dialogues.text: -- Just check the damn radio!

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: If I just CHECK, we might not have any juice left when we get to -- A sudden RUMBLE -- they all turn to look toward the SOUND coming from the OVERGROWN GRASS FIELD -- something LOUD - something COMING, FAST -- and they all FREEZE, afraid -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  78.

dialogues.speaker: BOONE
dialogues.text: -- The hell's that?

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON
dialogues.text: (quiet, sudden panic) -- oh God -- And they all turn to look -- to the distant, tall-growing GRASS -- PUSH IN on our characters -- KATE --

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: ...Something's coming -- Then we SMASH CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- We're RIPPING THROUGH THE GRASS at a SIDE-ANGLE -- A V

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and just as fast we SMASH CUT BACK TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHIP TO CHARLIE, TERRIFIED if under-stated:

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (choked voice) -- Coming towards us, I think...? -- Hell _ yeah, it is -- a hundred yards away and closing it's BIG, it's CHARGING, and it's KICKING UP DUST in the grown grass --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Another FAST, LOUD BLUR of a CHARGING CREATURE and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Kate's been through too much now -- she grabs Charlie the two run off --

dialogues.speaker: LET'S MOVE
dialogues.text: The RUMBLING CHARGE -- A SNORTING BEAST GETTING LOUDER -- Shannon just stands there, SCREAM-SHRIEKING OUT OF HER MI

dialogues.speaker: I_SHOULDN'T HAVE COME ON THIS
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  132 133 79.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: -- And Boone grabs her and YANKS her away and Kate is RUN to, she turns back to Sawyer, who stands there alone, intensely facing whatever's coming -- and Kate yells:

dialogues.speaker: NO, SAWYER
dialogues.text: But Sawyer doesn't move -- instead he does something wild surprising: HE PULLS OUT A GUN AND BEGINS FIRING AT THE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Kate and the others stop, shocked, watching in out-of breath horror as Sawyer FIRES, AGAIN AND AGAIN and the th gets CLOSER AND CLOSER UNTIL SAWYER'S GUN FIRES OUT AND

dialogues.speaker: BURSTS OUT, FALLING TO THE DIRTY GROUND, DEAD
dialogues.text: and heaving its last breaths only two feet away from Sawy who stares, in shock... ..-At_a giant WHITE BEAR. And now we're on Charlie, Shannon, Sayid and Boone -- all them, in total mind-bending shock at what's just happened Out of breath, they all walk over to the beast, which inh and then exhales for the last time. A long beat, then: SHANNON (CONT’D) ...-That's... that's a big bear.

dialogues.speaker: BOONE
dialogues.text: -- You think... that's what killed the pilot? Kate throws a look at Charlie -- this is exactly why he should have kept his mouth shut. But as the cat is alread out of the bag --

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: That? No. No, that's maybe a little tiny preemie baby version -- this is nothing compared to that --

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: -- Guys? This isn't just a bear. (beat) It's a polar bear. And they're all staring, incredulous...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVE PAST PRESCRIPTION BOTTLES, a pair of SCISSORS. THE SEWING KIT. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  133 80.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: CLEAN WHITE T-SHIRT torn into STRIPS -- makeshift BANDAGE THE STRAIGHT RAZOR. A REMOVED SINK BASIN FROM THE LAV, fu of water. PAN UP TO REVEAL -- Jack has built a makeshift TENT out of the deflated LIFE over Shrapnel Man, now stripped down to his waist. Hurley here. Leans over the "patient" --

dialogues.speaker: HURLEY
dialogues.text: You sure he's out?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: He's out.

dialogues.speaker: HURLEY
dialogues.text: How do you know he won't wake up when you pull that thing out?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (flips open razor) I don't. Hurley doesn't exactly feel reassured by this information Moves in real close over Shrapnel Man --

dialogues.speaker: HURLEY
dialogues.text: Hey, guy -- you awake? (louder) Yo! There's a rescue Plane! Hey! (nothing) Yeah, he's out. Jack passes the blade over the flame of a LIGHTER. Hurley pale --

dialogues.speaker: HURLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: +..-So what do I --

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: -- It's unlikely he'll regain consciousness, but the pain might bring him around. If it does... I need you to hold him down.

dialogues.speaker: HURLEY
dialogues.text: Uh -- I'm not so good around blood, man.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Then don't look.

dialogues.speaker: HURLEY
dialogues.text: Yeah. But I'm not so good around blood. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  81.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Just do your best, okay? Jack puts the lighter down, then puts both hands on the shrapnel.

dialogues.speaker: HURLEY
dialogues.text: Shouldn't you like, wash your hands?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I did. But he'll probably get infected no matter what I do. He lives, we just hope the antibiotics work. Don't look.

dialogues.speaker: HURLEY
dialogues.text: (turns away) Okay... Mutters something to himself. Maybe a silent prayer. A TENSE MOMENT... and then, suddenly Jack YANKS THE SHRAPNE FROM THE MAN'S BELLY as we -- SMASH CUT TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: END ACT SIX
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  82.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seconds after Jack has pulled out the shrapnel -- Jack do his best to assess the wound, now bleeding profusely. Hur has neglected his duty in holding Shrapnel Man down, in awe/disgust/shock about what's happening in front of him

dialogues.speaker: HURLEY JACK
dialogues.text: Dude... Hand me those strips -- And thank fucking God most of this happening below frame because Jack actually just put his hand inside the guy.

dialogues.speaker: HURLEY JACK
dialogues.text: Dude. Just hand me the strips -- I need to get this blood -- -- I don't think I can -- (feels something; it ain't good) -- Oh. -- "Oh." Oh what? What's going on? Is there something in there -- -- I need a little focus, okay? The strips. Just hand me the -- But Hurley in fact cannot focus. He's looking at the open wound, eyes glazing over. Jack sees it --

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Hey! Don't even think about -- HURLEY! But it's too late. Hurley crumples, hits the ground like bag of rocks -- PASSED OUT.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dammit. And as he does his best to refocus on the task at hand --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group -- still reacting to the almost-dead POLAR BEAR Sawyer, eyes on the bear, shoves his gun into the back of pants.

dialogues.speaker: BOONE
dialogues.text: ...That can't... be a polar be--

dialogues.speaker: KATE SAWYER
dialogues.text: It's a polar bear. It's a polar bear. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  135

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. Wait a minute. I never... finished college. But... polar bears don't... normally live in the jungle, right?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, spot-on. No, they don't. This is a freakshow --

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (to Sayid) Have you ever heard of anything like this?

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: No, this is, uh... polar bears don't live near this far south --

dialogues.speaker: BOONE
dialogues.text: -- This one does.

dialogues.speaker: SAWYER
dialogues.text: Did. Did. You're welcome for that. And Kate turns to him. Tough.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Where did that come from.

dialogues.speaker: SAWYER
dialogues.text: Prob'ly Bear Village. How the hell do I know --

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: -- Not the bear, the gun.

dialogues.speaker: SAWYER
dialogues.text: I got it off one of the bodies.

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: (confronting him too) One of the bodies.

dialogues.speaker: SAWYER
dialogues.text: (fuck you) Yeah, one of the bodies.

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON
dialogues.text: People don't carry guns on planes! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  135

dialogues.speaker: SAWYER
dialogues.text: They do if they're a U.S. Marshal! There was one on the plane --

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: -- How do you know that?!

dialogues.speaker: SAWYER
dialogues.text: ‘Cause I saw a guy lying there with an ankle holster -- so I took the gun, thought it might come in handy, guess what, it did!

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: -- Why do you think he was a Marshal?

dialogues.speaker: SAWYER
dialogues.text: Because he had a clip-on badge! (WHIPS OUT THE BADGE, angry) Took that too! Thought it was cool! Listen, Sweetheart, you should be kissing my ass after what I just did for you!

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: I_know who you are. You're the prisoner.

dialogues.speaker: SAWYER
dialogues.text: (beat) «-.-I'm the what?

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: You found_a_gun on awU.S. Marshal? Yes, I believe you did. You knew it was there because you were the one he was bringing back to the States. Those handcuffs were on you. (everyone stares at Sawyer, nervous ) That's how you knew there was a gun --

dialogues.speaker: SAWYER
dialogues.text: -- Hey, guess what, screw you!

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: That's who you are, you son-of-a-bitch!

dialogues.speaker: SAWYER
dialogues.text: Be as suspicious of me as I am of you -- go ahead!

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: You accuse me, but you are the prisoner! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  135 85.

dialogues.speaker: SAWYER
dialogues.text: -- Fine, I'm the criminal! You're the terrorist, we can all play a part! (to Shannon) Who do you wanna be? I'll tell ya what you should be! And in the middle of their argument KATE GRABS THE GUN FR SAWYER'S PANTS -- Sawyer swings around --

dialogues.speaker: HEY
dialogues.text: But Kate stands there, defiantly holding the gun on Sawye Everyone just freezes -- TENSE --

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Who knows how to use a gun?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I think you just pull the trigger. But Kate, we just escaped death, let's not push our luck --

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I want to take it apart.

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: There's a button on the grip -- push that, it will eject the magazine. And Kate does it: it POPS out with a solid metallic SNAP.

dialogues.speaker: SAYID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But there's still a round in the chamber -- hold the grip, pull back on the top part of the gun -- She does that -- the bullet POPS out. She tosses Sayid th clip. She picks up the bullet. Hands Sawyer the worthless gun. He takes it, somehow amused by her.

dialogues.speaker: SAWYER
dialogues.text: I know your type.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I'm not so sure.

dialogues.speaker: SAWYER
dialogues.text: Yeah, I've been with girls like you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  86.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Not girls exactly like me. Sawyer's amused by her. And he just walks away -- and we HOLD ON KATE for a long beat as she watches him go... fin

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Can I get you a refill? And Kate looks up as we CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're looking up at the FLIGHT ATTENDANT -- and realize t we're back on the plane. The moments before the trouble. And the Flight Attendant is talking to KATE, who looks up her -- and as if having to hide some deep trouble, kindly says about her almost-empty cup of Coke:

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: No, I'm fine with this, thank you. The Flight Attendant turns to the MAN sitting beside Kate

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: -- You, sir?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (to her chest) I'll have a coffee, sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: -- Coffee, sure -- And the Flight Attendant moves away. The Man glances at Kate. Kate stares out the window, pensive. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: You look worried. (she says nothing) I'd be worried too, I was you. Kate's eyes just stare at the blue out there.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey -- look at the bright side. There's an off-chance they'll believe your story. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  136 87.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (tongue firmly in cheek) I sure know I do. Kate finally looks at him. An intense stare. For a reason we're about to learn, she resents this man.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter to me what you believe. He grins. If it wasn't clear before, it's clear now -- th guy is a Class-A prickfuck.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Well that sure is true. Always has been. (long beat) You sure you don't want another soda?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: (defiant) Yeah, thanks. Then she goes to take a final sip -- and what we see shoc us. KATE IS WEARING THE HANDCUFFS.

dialogues.speaker: SHIT, SHE'S THE ONE THE U.S. MARSHAL WAS TAKING BACK TO T
dialogues.text: STATES ~—- AND THE MAN BESIDE HER IS THAT MARSHAL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she finishes her drink, the PLANE SHAKES. Just a littl No big deal. DING -- "FASTEN SEATBELTS" LIGHTS UP.

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT ATTENDANT'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentleman, the pilot has turned on the fasten seatbelts sign -- please return to your seats with your seatbelts fastened... And Kate turns to the man.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: I have one favor to ask.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: This oughta be good. Wh--

dialogues.speaker: COMES DOWN, HITTING THE MAN BESIDE KATE
dialogues.text: UNCONSCIOUS AS THE PLANE HITS HORRIBLE TURBULENCE -—— Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  137 138 139 140 141 142 88.

dialogues.speaker: PASSENGERS SCREAMING
dialogues.text: -- AND THE PLANE DROPS -- it's MAYHEM as the thing is abo to break up and the OXYGEN MASKS DROP NOW and people scra to grab them -- Kate tries too -- BUT HER CUFFS ARE ATTACHED TO HER BELT -~— SHE CAN'T REAC

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SCRAMBLES TO UNLOCK HER CUFFS -~— SHE DOES -- AND SHE GRA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just where we left Kate -- as the others walk off, follow Sawyer. Sayid then moves to Kate, who's pale now. And he says to her, sweetly:

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: -- We should keep moving. And Kate nods -- and heads off --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurley still out fucking cold, Jack continues his surgery Up to his elbows in blood. His patient, now clearly identifiable as the MARSHAL who flew with Kate. We don't see what Jack is doing, but it has a frantic fee it. Clearly get the sense that things have gone from bad worse. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  142 143 89.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: His hands move on autopilot -- using the torn shirt to so up the blood with his left hand -- holds the needle and thread in his right, trying to stitch up whatever is torn inside -- A desperate attempt to stick his thumb in the d that is this guy's life. And that's when --

dialogues.speaker: SHRAPNEL MAN
dialogues.text: Gah --- Jack FREEZES -- the Man's face is contorting in pain as h begins to GAIN CONSCIOUSNESS --

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: -- No -- The guy is literally struggling to breathe -- but he's conscious now. Moving his lips, something coming out ina whisper -- the guy is WILLING himself to say something -- Jack puts down the needle -- leans closer --

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What? I can't... And suddenly, the guy GRABS Jack by the shirt. Pulls him close with his last ounce of strength. And he HISSES --

dialogues.speaker: WHERE IS SHE
dialogues.text: Off Jack's face --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT ON A SMALL LEAF (known as "Sleeping Grass"). A smal hand touches it -- and the LEAF CLOSES. RACK FOCUS TO REV Walt, sitting on the sand, studying this odd plant. After a beat he HEARS:

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Walt! And Walt turns around -- across the beach, he sees his father.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You looking for this? Walt looks, curious. And Michael steps forward -- REVEALI VINCENT, WALT'S WHITE LAB. Walt's face comes to life as h RACES across the sand to the dog, who runs to Walt. Walt hugs the dog, loving him. Michael watches this. He can't help but smile at the reunion. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  143 144 145 90.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Then Michael looks over to Jack -- who kneels over the Ma with the shrapnel wound. And Jack is talking to the Man - and Michael watches this from a distance -- can't hear anything -- but what Michael sees is fascinating. The Man -- the Marshal -- is telling Jack something. Something urgent -- and Jack's reaction is shock. Disbeli And the Man -- holding on to Jack's lapel -- dies. And Ja stares at him, stunned. Michael watches as Jack finally sits back, exhausted, shocked. And Michael watches him, intrigued. We're TIGHT ON JACK -- LONG LONG LENS -- as he looks off, mind spinning --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're TIGHT ON KATE as she walks, staring off, numb... reliving her last moments on that airplane... HOLD ON HER a long beat.

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: Also walking. He pulls out the transceiver as they go. Sawyer sees this.

dialogues.speaker: SAWYER
dialogues.text: Oh. Now it's a good time to check the radio. Not before, but now.

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: We're up higher.

dialogues.speaker: SAWYER
dialogues.text: (asshole) Yes, we are. Sawyer walks off, past Sayid as Sayid turns on the radio. Stares at the screen. And he walks up to camera and stops now in EXTREME CLOSEUP.
TIGHT: A BAR FLICKERS in the RECEPTION window -- Sayid's shocked -- breathless -- Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  91.

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: -- Bar -- bar, there's a bar-- (then, loud)

dialogues.speaker: HEY
dialogues.text: The Others stop -- turn to him -- Sayid fiddles with the controls as the others surround him -- he holds down a bu and makes the call:

dialogues.speaker: SAYID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -- Mayday mayday-- But: SCRRRRREEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEE! HORRIBLE FEEDBACK!

dialogues.speaker: KATE SAYID
dialogues.text: -- What's that? -- Feedback -- - Feedback from what? -- I don't know --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- What would do that?

dialogues.speaker: SAWYER
dialogues.text: I'll tell you what would do that. This guy not fixing the radio -- the thing doesn't work -- And once again: SCRRRRRREEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEE! Sayid releases the button --

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: No -- no, it's not broken... (suddenly) We can't transmit because something's already transmitting. This sinks in --

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What? Transmitting from where?

dialogues.speaker: SAYID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Somewhere close -- the signal's strong --

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Close? You mean here on the island close? That's fantastic!

dialogues.speaker: BOONE
dialogues.text: Maybe it's other survivors --

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON SAWYER
dialogues.text: From our plane? How -- So what kind of "transmission" is it? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  92.

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: Could be a Satphone -- maybe a radio signal... TIGHT ON KATE as she finally asks the only question reall worth answering --

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Can we listen to it?

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: I don't know what frequency the signal is -- hold on -- Sayid begins to SCAN for the frequency -- nothing but STA

dialogues.speaker: SAWYER KATE
dialogues.text: -- There's no transmission -- Sawyer, shut-up --

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: It's the rescue crew -- it must be -- And suddenly GASPS from the group as they HEAR A FRANTIC

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...-Il est dehors... Il est dehors et Brennan pris les clefs!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: -- That's French. The French are coming! I've never been so grateful for the French -- Our people can't believe they're actually hearing another voice:

dialogues.speaker: KATE FEMALE VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I never took French -- -- Veuillez nous aider... Ils What's she saying? sont morts -- Ils sont tous morts...

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: -- Does anyone speak French? MOVING over all their faces as the voice continues. No. None of them speak French. But then -- pointing:

dialogues.speaker: BOONE
dialogues.text: She does. Boone's pointing at Shannon. And not since Algebra 2 has Shannon been on the spot like this. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  93.

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON
dialogues.text: What?!? No I don't...

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: And now another VOICE emerges from the walkie. A MALE VOI oddly flat. Without inflection. Automaton --

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Iteration one seven two nine four five three one.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (fucking befuddled) Right then -- what was that? But now the FRENCH WOMAN is speaking again. And her voice FADING a little...

dialogues.speaker: SAYID KATE
dialogues.text: -- Nonono -- -- What? "Nonono" what? -- The batteries -- they're dying --

dialogues.speaker: BOONE
dialogues.text: (to Shannon)

dialogues.speaker: THIS
dialogues.text: Shannon tries to understand it -- shaking, her eyes close Kate's nervous --

dialogues.speaker: KATE SAYID
dialogues.text: How much time do we -- ? -- Not much --

dialogues.speaker: SAWYER
dialogues.text: You're telling me no one here speaks French?! ?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE MALE VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: -- That voice -- that's Iteration one seven two nine weird -- four five three two. And THE DESPERATE FEMALE VOICE begins again...

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: -- Nous aider... Ils sont (small voice) morts -- It's -- it's repeating -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  94.

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: -- Yes, she's right -- It's a loop. "Iteration." It's repeating the same message. (and to prove it) It's a counter -- the next number will end five three three. And they HUSH, focused on the transceiver as --

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Iteration one seven two nine four five three three. Beat. Then, the FRENCH WOMAN begins again, still FAINTER Sayid looks up at the others, triumphant.

dialogues.speaker: SAWYER
dialogues.text: Does anyone understand what the hell he's talking about?

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: It's a running count. Of the number of times the message has repeated. It's roughly thirty seconds long, so... Sayid's eyes look skyward, lips moving -- runs the number

dialogues.speaker: SAWYER
dialogues.text: Don't forget to carry the one, chief.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE KATE
dialogues.text: -- Guys, the battery -- Give him a minute. Boone couldn't care less about figuring out the numbers. is still intent on his sister --

dialogues.speaker: BOONE
dialogues.text: -- C'mon, Shan -- What's she saying? Try.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Si n'importe qui peut (scrambling; stressed) entendre ceci -- veuillez -- I don't know -- I think nous aider... she's saying "Please." (listens) She's saying "Please help me. Please come get me."

dialogues.speaker: SAWYER
dialogues.text: (losing his shit) Or she's not! You don't speak French! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  146 95.

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Let her listen.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Il les a tues. I1 les a tues tous. And Shannon's face FALLS as she listens, something registering... and whatever it is, it scares the LIVING S OUT OF HER.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What? What is it? The voice gets fainter and fainter. Shannon brings the walkie to her ear, she's calm now, almost as if she's CHANNELING the speaker. And yeah -- it's fucking SPOOKY..

dialogues.speaker: SHANNON
dialogues.text: "Please help... I'm alone now... on the island alone. Someone please come... the others, they're dead. It killed them. (then) It killed them all." And with that, complete and utter SILENCE. The battery is dead. Just the wind. Then Shannon lowers the transceiver. We suddenly find SAYID. His lips stop moving. His eyes dr from the heavens. And he looks even more frightened than rest of them.

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: Sixteen years.

dialogues.speaker: SAWYER
dialogues.text: (snapping out of it) What?

dialogues.speaker: SAYID
dialogues.text: Sixteen years. Five months. And nine days. That's the count.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE BOONE
dialogues.text: The count? What -- ? You wanna give us a minute here, man? ‘Cause this is --

dialogues.speaker: SAYID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The message. The iterations. It's a distress call. A mayday. A plea for help. And if the counter's right, it's been playing... over and over for sixteen years. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  96.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: And we let that doozy sink in for a moment before --

dialogues.speaker: BOONE
dialogues.text: Someone else was stranded here?

dialogues.speaker: KATE
dialogues.text: Maybe someone came for them...

dialogues.speaker: SAWYER
dialogues.text: If someone came, why's it still playing? Beat. Another beat. And another. Taking in all six of them. All equally freaked... no longer so sure they were lucky to survive. Finally --

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Guys -- where are we? CUT TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: THE END
